> 🔗 Anvisa RDC 441/2020: https://www.in.gov.br/en/web/dou/-/resolucao-rdc-n-441-de-12-de-novembro-de-2020-287293332

## 3. Technical Documentation and Patents

### 3.1 Patents Related to CL1

To date, no patent has been identified under the designation "CL1" in databases such as the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO) or IP Australia. However, Cortical Labs is known to operate based on proprietary know-how and confidential research, which is common in early-stage deep tech startups.

The lack of publicly available patents could mean:
- The patent is under review and has not yet been published;
- The company has opted for trade secret strategies;
- Key technologies are protected under broader patent families related to biointerfaces, neuronal culture, or neuro-silicon integration.

Searches for terms like “brain-on-a-chip”, “neuronal networks on silicon” or “biological computing with human neurons” may reveal related patents from other entities.

### 3.2 Technical Features of the CL1

According to Cortical Labs, the CL1 system includes:

- A self-contained physical unit with embedded life support (gases, pumps, thermal control);
- Up to 6 months of viability for neuronal cultures;
- Bidirectional electrical interface (MEA) enabling stimulus and data collection;
- Real-time signal processing by biological networks;
- USB and peripheral connectivity;
- Integration with biOS – a biological operating system developed in-house.

The system does not require an external computer to run its core functions and is designed for use in laboratories without cleanroom environments.

### 3.3 Remote Access and Cloud Platform

Cortical Labs also offers **Cortical Cloud**, a cloud-based remote access platform that enables researchers to execute code on real neural networks hosted on their servers. This model facilitates access to biocomputing resources without physical hardware.

More details: [https://corticallabs.com/cl1.html](https://corticallabs.com/cl1.html)

## 4. Scientific Applications and Technical Challenges

The CL1 is promoted as a tool for research in:

- Real-time signal processing;
- Neuromorphic computation;
- Experimental neurobiology;
- Biofeedback and adaptive learning models.

Challenges include:

- Biological reproducibility of responses;
- Data acquisition and interface standardization;
- Long-term viability and neural drift;
- Ethical limitations on experimental protocols.

Use cases suggest potential integration with robotics, pattern recognition systems, and cognitive modeling.

## 5. Related Projects and International Landscape

### 5.1 FinalSpark (Switzerland)

FinalSpark is developing a bioprocessor using human neurons and microfluidic chambers. The system is remotely accessible and offers API-level integration. It is in the prototype phase.

- [https://www.finalspark.com](https://www.finalspark.com)

### 5.2 Brainoware (Japan/USA)

Published in *Nature Electronics* (2023), Brainoware combines brain organoids with optical neural interfaces. The system learns to classify auditory stimuli.

- [Nature Electronics – 2023](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41928-023-01095-8)

### 5.3 DishBrain and Koniku

DishBrain, published by Cortical Labs in 2022 (*Neuron*), demonstrated real-time learning in MEA cultures playing Pong. Koniku, a US company, integrates olfactory neurons with neuromorphic platforms for chemical detection.

- [Kagan et al., 2022 – Neuron](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neuron.2022.09.001)  
- [https://www.koniku.com](https://www.koniku.com)

### 5.4 Comparison Table

| Project       | Country      | Cell Type               | Access      | Status                  |
|---------------|--------------|--------------------------|-------------|--------------------------|
| CL1           | Australia    | hiPSCs-derived neurons   | Commercial  | Available                |
| FinalSpark    | Switzerland  | Human neurons            | API/Remote  | Prototype                |
| Brainoware    | Japan/USA    | Brain organoids          | Research    | Published (2023)         |
| DishBrain     | Australia    | hiPSCs-derived neurons   | Research    | Integrated in CL1        |
| Koniku        | USA          | Olfactory cells          | Proprietary | Military/security tests  |

## 6. Final Considerations and Recommendations

The CL1 system represents a pioneering development in biocomputing platforms using live human neurons. Despite its commercial availability and innovative approach, its adoption requires thorough institutional scrutiny.

Key concerns include:
- Documentation of ethical sourcing of biological material;
- Transparency of consent and transfer protocols;
- Long-term scientific reproducibility;
- Intellectual property clarity.

Recommendations for ICB-USP:

1. Formally request detailed documentation from Cortical Labs;
2. Consult the institution's Research Ethics Committee (CEP);
3. Evaluate academic feasibility via neuroscience and AI groups at USP;
4. Maintain monitoring of global projects for benchmarking.

This report is intended to support decision-making processes within a scientifically grounded and ethically sound framework.

content.text: search("onde se iniciou a pesquisa com sistemas de computa\u00e7ao h\u00edbrida ?")

parts:
A pesquisa em sistemas de computação híbrida, que combinam componentes analógicos e digitais, teve início no início da década de 1960. Um dos primeiros exemplos notáveis foi o Hycomp 250, lançado pela Packard Bell em 1961. Pouco depois, em 1963, a EAI introduziu o HYDAC 2400, outro sistema híbrido integrado. citeturn0search1

Esses sistemas foram desenvolvidos para aproveitar as vantagens dos computadores analógicos em resolver equações diferenciais complexas rapidamente, enquanto utilizavam a precisão e a flexibilidade dos computadores digitais para controle e processamento de dados. Durante a Guerra Fria, por exemplo, computadores híbridos foram empregados em sistemas de mísseis balísticos intercontinentais (ICBMs) e nos cálculos que possibilitaram as missões tripuladas à Lua no Programa Apollo. citeturn0search3

Com o avanço da tecnologia digital nas décadas seguintes, o uso de sistemas híbridos diminuiu, pois os computadores digitais começaram a suprir muitas das funções anteriormente desempenhadas por sistemas analógicos. No entanto, o conceito de computação híbrida ressurgiu em diferentes contextos, como na integração de computação clássica e quântica, conhecida como computação quântica híbrida, onde computadores quânticos e clássicos trabalham juntos para resolver problemas complexos. citeturn0search7

parts: assim como o sistema computacional sofre com a invasao de viruas, a parte biológica do sistema poderia sofrer com a açao de virus físicos ou lógicos ou outras patologias ?

Sim, Marcos — essa é uma excelente e pertinente reflexão, sobretudo no contexto de sistemas híbridos bio-máquina com neurônios humanos. A resposta é **sim, tanto vírus biológicos quanto ataques lógicos (digitais)** podem afetar o sistema, cada um à sua maneira:

---

### 🧬 **Ameaças Biológicas ao Sistema (Vírus e Patógenos Reais)**

Os neurônios utilizados em sistemas como o CL1 ou FinalSpark são células vivas, cultivadas em ambiente controlado. Assim, **podem ser vulneráveis a agentes infecciosos reais**, como:

- **Vírus neurotrópicos**, como Zika, Herpes ou SARS-CoV-2 (que possui tropismo por tecidos neurais);
- **Contaminações bacterianas ou fúngicas**, caso haja falha no suporte de vida ou na esterilidade do sistema;
- **Respostas inflamatórias celulares** ou **degeneração espontânea**, em especial em cultivos prolongados.

🔬 Há inclusive artigos como o [“Interfer(on)ing with Zika Virus”](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-019-1449-6) que discutem **como certos vírus podem alterar a fisiologia de neurônios em cultura**.

---

### 💻 **Ameaças Digitais e de Segurança da Informação (Vírus Lógicos)**

Por outro lado, sistemas como o CL1 estão conectados digitalmente — tanto local quanto remotamente (via **Cortical Cloud** por exemplo) — e podem sofrer:

- **Ataques cibernéticos**, como ransomware ou malware, que poderiam comprometer a interpretação dos sinais neurais ou mesmo estimular os neurônios incorretamente;
- **Manipulação maliciosa dos dados de entrada**, levando a alterações nos padrões de resposta da rede neural viva;
- **Espionagem científica**, dado que esses sistemas podem carregar dados de alta sensibilidade.

---

### 🧠 **Consequências e Implicações Éticas**

Um ataque, seja biológico ou digital, pode:

- **Danificar permanentemente a cultura neural viva**, o que representa perda de material biológico sensível e potencialmente ético;
- **Gerar decisões erradas em sistemas embarcados**, caso o biochip seja usado em controle de máquinas;
- **Violar princípios da bioética**, se houver sofrimento celular evitável ou uso indevido de material humano.

---

      "replacement": "# Preliminary Report on the CL1 System  
**Version 1.1.1 – April 3, 2025**  
**Institute of Biomedical Sciences – University of São Paulo (ICB-USP)**  
**Location: São Paulo, SP – Brazil**

---

## 1. Introduction

This report presents a preliminary analysis of the CL1 system developed by Cortical Labs, an autonomous hybrid biocomputing platform composed of live human neurons cultured on microelectrode arrays (MEA) integrated with electronic circuits.

The document is intended to support an institutional review of the ethical, legal, technical, and scientific implications of adopting this type of technology at the Institute of Biomedical Sciences (ICB-USP), especially in the context of research on artificial intelligence, biological computing, and information security.

The report is structured in the following sections:

- **Section 2** – Ethical, Legal, and Regulatory Aspects  
- **Section 3** – Technical Documentation and Patents  
- **Section 4** – Scientific Applications and Technical Challenges  
- **Section 5** – Related Projects and International Landscape  
- **Section 6** – Final Considerations and Recommendations  
- **Section 7** – Biological and Digital Security Risks (NEW)

The report version 1.1.1 incorporates recent updates, including academic publications, data available from the company's official website, and comparative analysis of international projects. It replaces the previous draft and consolidates the content under a critical and scientific approach, without commercial or promotional influence.

...

## 7. Biological and Digital Security Risks

### 7.1 Biological Contamination and Vulnerabilities

Because the CL1 system uses live human neurons in culture, it is susceptible to contamination by biological agents. Pathogens such as viruses (e.g., Zika, HSV-1, SARS-CoV-2), bacteria, or fungi could compromise the viability or function of the culture if biosafety protocols fail.

- Certain viruses exhibit neurotropism (affinity for neural tissue), and may alter electrophysiological patterns or cellular integrity.
- Research has shown that Zika virus, for instance, can induce direct damage to cultured neurons and organoids (Garcez et al., 2016).

> Garcez PP et al. Zika virus impairs growth in human neurospheres and brain organoids. *Science*. 2016;352(6287):816–818. https://doi.org/10.1126/science.aaf6116

### 7.2 Cybersecurity and Logical Threats

Being a system with remote access (e.g., via Cortical Cloud), CL1 is also exposed to digital risks:

- Malware or ransomware could disrupt neural stimulation protocols or compromise recorded data;
- Adversarial attacks could intentionally manipulate the neuronal input-output interface, leading to unpredictable behaviors;
- Intellectual property and data privacy risks emerge if cloud communications are not encrypted.

As with any hybrid system, where biological and electronic domains interact, the **attack surface becomes multidimensional**, demanding biosecurity and cybersecurity policies.

### 7.3 Ethical Implications of Breaches

Any biological damage to neural cultures—accidental or malicious—may raise ethical concerns, particularly if linked to sentience or adaptive responses in the tissue. Institutions must prepare protocols for:

- Traceability of experimental stimuli;
- Emergency destruction of cultures under threat;
- Audits and logs of remote access sessions.

Including a biosecurity and digital risk assessment in the implementation phase is a critical step to ensure the responsible use of hybrid biocomputing systems."
    }
  ]
}

This report presents a preliminary analysis of the CL1 system developed by Cortical Labs, an autonomous hybrid biocomputing platform composed of live human neurons cultured on microelectrode arrays (MEA) integrated with electronic circuits.

The document is intended to support an institutional review of the ethical, legal, technical, and scientific implications of adopting this type of technology at the Institute of Biomedical Sciences (ICB-USP), especially in the context of research on artificial intelligence, biological computing, and information security.

The report is structured in the following sections:

- **Section 2** – Ethical, Legal, and Regulatory Aspects  
- **Section 3** – Technical Documentation and Patents  
- **Section 4** – Scientific Applications and Technical Challenges  
- **Section 5** – Related Projects and International Landscape  
- **Section 6** – Biological and Digital Security Risks  
- **Section 7** – Final Considerations and Recommendations

The report version 1.1.2 builds upon version 1.1.1, preserving its content and structure while reorganizing the position of the new risk assessment section for improved coherence.

## 2. Ethical, Legal, and Regulatory Aspects

[...]

## 4. Scientific Applications and Technical Challenges

## 5. Related Projects and International Landscape

## 6. Biological and Digital Security Risks

### 6.1 Biological Contamination and Vulnerabilities

Because the CL1 system uses live human neurons in culture, it is susceptible to contamination by biological agents. Pathogens such as viruses (e.g., Zika, HSV-1, SARS-CoV-2), bacteria, or fungi could compromise the viability or function of the culture if biosafety protocols fail.

- Certain viruses exhibit neurotropism (affinity for neural tissue), and may alter electrophysiological patterns or cellular integrity.
- Research has shown that Zika virus, for instance, can induce direct damage to cultured neurons and organoids (Garcez et al., 2016).

> Garcez PP et al. Zika virus impairs growth in human neurospheres and brain organoids. *Science*. 2016;352(6287):816–818. https://doi.org/10.1126/science.aaf6116

### 6.2 Cybersecurity and Logical Threats

Being a system with remote access (e.g., via Cortical Cloud), CL1 is also exposed to digital risks:

- Malware or ransomware could disrupt neural stimulation protocols or compromise recorded data;
- Adversarial attacks could intentionally manipulate the neuronal input-output interface, leading to unpredictable behaviors;
- Intellectual property and data privacy risks emerge if cloud communications are not encrypted.

As with any hybrid system, where biological and electronic domains interact, the **attack surface becomes multidimensional**, demanding biosecurity and cybersecurity policies.

### 6.3 Ethical Implications of Breaches

Any biological damage to neural cultures—accidental or malicious—may raise ethical concerns, particularly if linked to sentience or adaptive responses in the tissue. Institutions must prepare protocols for:

- Traceability of experimental stimuli;
- Emergency destruction of cultures under threat;
- Audits and logs of remote access sessions.

Including a biosecurity and digital risk assessment in the implementation phase is a critical step to ensure the responsible use of hybrid biocomputing systems.

## 7. Final Considerations and Recommendations

The CL1 system represents a pioneering development in biocomputing platforms using live human neurons. Despite its commercial availability and innovative approach, its adoption requires thorough institutional scrutiny.

Key concerns include:
- Documentation of ethical sourcing of biological material;
- Transparency of consent and transfer protocols;
- Long-term scientific reproducibility;
- Intellectual property clarity.

Recommendations for ICB-USP:

1. Formally request detailed documentation from Cortical Labs;
2. Consult the institution's Research Ethics Committee (CEP);
3. Evaluate academic feasibility via neuroscience and AI groups at USP;
4. Maintain monitoring of global projects for benchmarking.

This report is intended to support decision-making processes within a scientifically grounded and ethically sound framework."

## 2. Ethical, Legal, and Regulatory Aspects

### 2.1 Ethical Issues Regarding the Use of Human Neurons

The CL1 system uses human neurons cultivated from induced pluripotent stem cells (hiPSCs) obtained from neonatal foreskin fibroblasts. This methodology was detailed in the publication by Kagan et al. (2022), which describes the reprogramming process using the STEMCCA-loxP system and subsequent neuronal differentiation through Dual SMAD Inhibition and NGN2 induction protocols.

Despite the publication's transparency regarding the origin and lineage of the cells, Cortical Labs does not make public the full bioethical documentation, such as informed consent forms, ethics committee approvals, or the Material Transfer Agreement (MTA). This limitation poses concerns in terms of compliance with Brazilian research regulations.

In Brazil, the use of human biological material in research is regulated by the National Health Council (CNS), through Resolution CNS 580/2018, which complements Resolution CNS 510/2016. Article 15 of CNS 580 establishes that research with human cells requires approval by a Research Ethics Committee (CEP) and registration on the Plataforma Brasil.

> 🔗 CNS Resolution 580/2018: https://conselho.saude.gov.br/resolucoes/2018/Reso580.pdf  
> 🔗 Plataforma Brasil (CONEP): https://plataformabrasil.saude.gov.br

Additionally, international documents such as the Universal Declaration on Bioethics and Human Rights (UNESCO, 2005) and the Declaration of Helsinki (WMA, 2013) establish principles that guide the ethical use of human biological material. Although Brazil is not a signatory to the Oviedo Convention (Council of Europe), the country adheres to the main principles of respect for autonomy, privacy, and transparency.

> 🔗 UNESCO Declaration: https://unesdoc.unesco.org/ark:/48223/pf0000146180  
> 🔗 Declaration of Helsinki: https://www.wma.net/policies-post/wma-declaration-of-helsinki

The absence of public access to the ethical documentation of the CL1 system restricts the possibility of its immediate adoption in the Brazilian academic context and requires a formal request for detailed documents from the company.

### 2.2 Regulatory Framework – National and International

From a legal and regulatory perspective, any technology using human biological material must comply with national health surveillance, biosafety, and ethics standards.

In Brazil, in addition to the CNS resolutions, the following standards apply:

- Law No. 11.105/2005 (Biosafety Law);  
- Law No. 13.709/2018 (General Data Protection Law – LGPD), if the biological data are associated with personal information;  
- Anvisa Resolution RDC 441/2020, on cell and gene therapy products.

At the international level, the European Union regulates similar procedures under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and Directive 2004/23/EC. The United States, although lacking a centralized legal framework, regulates the matter through the NIH and FDA.

In any case, the adoption of a system like CL1 in a Brazilian institution must be preceded by an institutional assessment by the CEP/CONEP system and possibly by Anvisa, depending on its intended use.

> 🔗 Law No. 11.105/2005 (Biosafety): https://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/_ato2004-2006/2005/lei/l11105.htm  
> 🔗 LGPD (Law No. 13.709/2018): https://www.gov.br/anpd/pt-br/assuntos/legislacao  
> 🔗 Anvisa RDC 441/2020: https://www.in.gov.br/en/web/dou/-/resolucao-rdc-n-441-de-12-de-novembro-de-2020-287293332

The CL1 system uses human neurons cultivated from induced pluripotent stem cells (hiPSCs) obtained from neonatal foreskin fibroblasts. This methodology was detailed in the publication by Kagan et al. (2022), which describes the reprogramming process using the STEMCCA-loxP system and subsequent neuronal differentiation through Dual SMAD Inhibition and NGN2 induction protocols.

Despite the publication's transparency regarding the origin and lineage of the cells, Cortical Labs does not make public the full bioethical documentation, such as informed consent forms, ethics committee approvals, or the Material Transfer Agreement (MTA). This limitation poses concerns in terms of compliance with Brazilian research regulations.

In Brazil, the use of human biological material in research is regulated by the National Health Council (CNS), through Resolution CNS 580/2018, which complements Resolution CNS 510/2016. Article 15 of CNS 580 establishes that research with human cells requires approval by a Research Ethics Committee (CEP) and registration on the Plataforma Brasil.

> 🔗 CNS Resolution 580/2018: https://conselho.saude.gov.br/resolucoes/2018/Reso580.pdf  
> 🔗 Plataforma Brasil (CONEP): https://plataformabrasil.saude.gov.br

Additionally, international documents such as the Universal Declaration on Bioethics and Human Rights (UNESCO, 2005) and the Declaration of Helsinki (WMA, 2013) establish principles that guide the ethical use of human biological material. Although Brazil is not a signatory to the Oviedo Convention (Council of Europe), the country adheres to the main principles of respect for autonomy, privacy, and transparency.

> 🔗 UNESCO Declaration: https://unesdoc.unesco.org/ark:/48223/pf0000146180  
> 🔗 Declaration of Helsinki: https://www.wma.net/policies-post/wma-declaration-of-helsinki

The absence of public access to the ethical documentation of the CL1 system restricts the possibility of its immediate adoption in the Brazilian academic context and requires a formal request for detailed documents from the company.

### 2.2 Regulatory Framework – National and International

This subsection presents an overview of the Brazilian and international legal frameworks applicable to the handling and implementation of systems based on human biological material.

In Brazil, in addition to the CNS resolutions, the following standards apply:

- Law No. 11.105/2005 (Biosafety Law);  
- Law No. 13.709/2018 (General Data Protection Law – LGPD), if the biological data are associated with personal information;  
- Anvisa Resolution RDC 441/2020, on cell and gene therapy products.

At the international level, the European Union regulates similar procedures under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and Directive 2004/23/EC. The United States, although lacking a centralized legal framework, regulates the matter through the NIH and FDA.

> 🔗 Law No. 11.105/2005 (Biosafety): https://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/_ato2004-2006/2005/lei/l11105.htm  
> 🔗 LGPD (Law No. 13.709/2018): https://www.gov.br/anpd/pt-br/assuntos/legislacao  
> 🔗 Anvisa RDC 441/2020: https://www.in.gov.br/en/web/dou/-/resolucao-rdc-n-441-de-12-de-novembro-de-2020-287293332

## 3. Technical Documentation and Patents

This section outlines the current public documentation on the CL1 system, the existence (or absence) of patents, and the technical characteristics disclosed by Cortical Labs.

### 3.1 Patents Related to CL1

To date, no patent has been identified under the designation "CL1" in the databases of the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO) or the Australian Patent Office. The company appears to operate using a combination of proprietary know-how and confidential research strategies.

The lack of published patents may indicate that:
- The technology is still under examination and not yet published;
- The company opted for trade secret strategies;
- The technical concepts are protected under broader patent families.

Searches for terms like “brain-on-a-chip” or “neuronal networks on silicon” may yield related technologies patented by other institutions or companies.

### 3.2 Technical Features of the CL1

The CL1 system is described by Cortical Labs as an autonomous biological computing platform composed of living human neurons interacting with an MEA and a set of sensors and actuators. Its features include:

- Standalone device with embedded life support;
- Cultures sustained for up to six months;
- Input/output based on electrical stimulation and real-time neural responses;
- Interaction with peripheral devices (USB, camera);
- A biological operating system (biOS).

It does not require external computing for operation and is intended for use even outside cleanroom environments.

### 3.3 Remote Access and Cloud Platform

The Cortical Cloud platform allows remote access to live neuron cultures hosted by the company. Researchers can send algorithms and analyze responses without local hardware.

> 🔗 Official site: https://corticallabs.com/cl1.html

## 4. Scientific Applications and Technical Challenges

## 6. Biological and Digital Security Risks

This section analyzes potential biological vulnerabilities and cybersecurity risks associated with the CL1 system, including ethical considerations related to attacks or failures.

### 6.1 Biological Contamination and Vulnerabilities

Because the CL1 system uses live human neurons in culture, it is susceptible to contamination by biological agents. Pathogens such as viruses (e.g., Zika, HSV-1, SARS-CoV-2), bacteria, or fungi could compromise the viability or function of the culture if biosafety protocols fail.

- Certain viruses exhibit neurotropism (affinity for neural tissue), and may alter electrophysiological patterns or cellular integrity.
- Research has shown that Zika virus, for instance, can induce direct damage to cultured neurons and organoids (Garcez et al., 2016).

> Garcez PP et al. Zika virus impairs growth in human neurospheres and brain organoids. *Science*. 2016;352(6287):816–818. https://doi.org/10.1126/science.aaf6116

### 6.2 Cybersecurity and Logical Threats

Being a system with remote access (e.g., via Cortical Cloud), CL1 is also exposed to digital risks:

- Malware or ransomware could disrupt neural stimulation protocols or compromise recorded data;
- Adversarial attacks could intentionally manipulate the neuronal input-output interface, leading to unpredictable behaviors;
- Intellectual property and data privacy risks emerge if cloud communications are not encrypted.

As with any hybrid system, where biological and electronic domains interact, the **attack surface becomes multidimensional**, demanding biosecurity and cybersecurity policies.

### 6.3 Ethical Implications of Breaches

Any biological damage to neural cultures—accidental or malicious—may raise ethical concerns, particularly if linked to sentience or adaptive responses in the tissue. Institutions must prepare protocols for:

- Traceability of experimental stimuli;
- Emergency destruction of cultures under threat;
- Audits and logs of remote access sessions.

Including a biosecurity and digital risk assessment in the implementation phase is a critical step to ensure the responsible use of hybrid biocomputing systems.

## 7. Final Considerations and Recommendations

This final section summarizes the conclusions of the report and provides recommendations for ICB-USP with respect to the adoption or further investigation of the CL1 system.

The CL1 system represents a pioneering development in biocomputing platforms using live human neurons. Despite its commercial availability and innovative approach, its adoption requires thorough institutional scrutiny.

Key concerns include:
- Documentation of ethical sourcing of biological material;
- Transparency of consent and transfer protocols;
- Long-term scientific reproducibility;
- Intellectual property clarity.

Recommendations for ICB-USP:

1. Formally request detailed documentation from Cortical Labs;
2. Consult the institution's Research Ethics Committee (CEP);
3. Evaluate academic feasibility via neuroscience and AI groups at USP;
4. Maintain monitoring of global projects for benchmarking.

This report is intended to support decision-making processes within a scientifically grounded and ethically sound framework."

## 1. Introdução

Este relatório apresenta uma análise preliminar do sistema CL1 desenvolvido pela Cortical Labs, uma plataforma autônoma de biocomputação híbrida composta por neurônios humanos vivos cultivados sobre matrizes de microeletrodos (MEA) integradas a circuitos eletrônicos.

O documento tem por objetivo subsidiar a avaliação institucional dos aspectos éticos, legais, técnicos e científicos envolvidos na eventual adoção dessa tecnologia no Instituto de Ciências Biomédicas da Universidade de São Paulo (ICB-USP), especialmente no contexto de pesquisas em inteligência artificial, computação biológica e segurança da informação.
